topics.title: Semiconductors

definition.text: Semiconductors are materials with electrical conductivity between conductors and insulators. Their conductivity can be modified by adding impurities (doping), temperature changes, or light exposure. Silicon and germanium are the most common semiconductor materials, forming the basis of modern electronics.

keyFormulas.name: Intrinsic Carrier Concentration
keyFormulas.meaning: n·µ¢ = carrier concentration, Nc = conduction band density, Nv = valence band density, Eg = bandgap, k = Boltzmann constant, T = temperature

keyFormulas.name: Semiconductor Conductivity
keyFormulas.meaning: œÉ = conductivity, q = electron charge, n = electron concentration, p = hole concentration, Œº = mobility

codeExample.python:
# Intrinsic carrier concentration calculation
import math

def intrinsic_carriers(Nc, Nv, Eg, T):
    k = 8.617e-5  # eV/K
    ni = math.sqrt(Nc * Nv) * math.exp(-Eg / (2 * k * T))
    return ni

# Silicon at room temperature
ni_si = intrinsic_carriers(2.8e19, 1.04e19, 1.12, 300)
print(f'ni (Si at 300K) = {ni_si:.2e} /cm¬≥')

topics.title: Diodes

definition.text: A diode is a two-terminal semiconductor device that allows current to flow in one direction only. When forward biased (positive voltage on anode), it conducts; when reverse biased, it blocks current. The voltage drop across a conducting silicon diode is approximately 0.7V.

keyFormulas.name: Shockley Diode Equation
keyFormulas.meaning: I = current, Is = saturation current, V = voltage, n = ideality factor, Vt = thermal voltage (‚âà26mV at room temp)

keyFormulas.name: Forward Voltage Drop
keyFormulas.meaning: Typical voltage drop across a conducting diode

codeExample.python:
# Diode I-V characteristic
import numpy as np

def diode_current(V, Is=1e-12, n=1, T=300):
    Vt = 0.0259  # Thermal voltage at 300K
    return Is * (np.exp(V / (n * Vt)) - 1)

# Plot characteristic
voltages = np.linspace(-0.5, 0.8, 100)
currents = diode_current(voltages)
print(f'At V=0.7V: I = {diode_current(0.7)*1000:.2f} mA')

topics.title: Bipolar Junction Transistors

definition.text: A BJT is a three-terminal semiconductor device (Base, Collector, Emitter) that can amplify current. A small base current controls a much larger collector current. BJTs come in NPN (electrons as majority carriers) and PNP (holes as majority carriers) types, acting as current-controlled current sources.

keyFormulas.name: Current Gain (Beta)
keyFormulas.meaning: Collector current is beta times base current

keyFormulas.name: Collector Current
keyFormulas.meaning: Small base current controls large collector current

keyFormulas.name: Emitter Current
keyFormulas.meaning: All current entering must exit through emitter

codeExample.python:
# BJT amplifier design
def bjt_amplifier(Vcc, Rc, Rb, beta, Vbe=0.7):
    # Calculate base current
    Ib = (Vcc - Vbe) / Rb
    # Calculate collector current
    Ic = beta * Ib
    # Calculate collector voltage
    Vc = Vcc - Ic * Rc
    return Ib, Ic, Vc

# Example: Common emitter amplifier
Vcc = 12  # Supply voltage
Rc = 1000  # 1kŒ© collector resistor
Rb = 100000  # 100kŒ© base resistor
beta = 200

Ib, Ic, Vc = bjt_amplifier(Vcc, Rc, Rb, beta)
print(f'Ib = {Ib*1e6:.1f} ¬µA')
print(f'Ic = {Ic*1e3:.1f} mA')
print(f'Vc = {Vc:.1f} V')

topics.title: Operational Amplifiers

definition.text: An operational amplifier (op-amp) is a high-gain differential voltage amplifier with two inputs (inverting and non-inverting) and one output. Ideal op-amps have infinite gain, infinite input impedance, and zero output impedance. With negative feedback, they form the basis for countless analog circuits.

keyFormulas.name: Inverting Amplifier Gain
keyFormulas.meaning: Gain is ratio of feedback to input resistance (negative = phase inversion)

keyFormulas.name: Non-Inverting Amplifier Gain
keyFormulas.meaning: Gain is always ‚â• 1, no phase inversion

keyFormulas.name: Gain-Bandwidth Product
keyFormulas.meaning: Higher gain means lower bandwidth; product is constant

codeExample.python:
# Op-amp circuit calculator
def inverting_amp(Vin, Rf, Rin):
    gain = -Rf / Rin
    Vout = gain * Vin
    return gain, Vout

def non_inverting_amp(Vin, Rf, Rin):
    gain = 1 + Rf / Rin
    Vout = gain * Vin
    return gain, Vout

# Example: Audio preamp
Rf = 100000  # 100kŒ©
Rin = 10000  # 10kŒ©
Vin = 0.1    # 100mV input

gain, Vout = non_inverting_amp(Vin, Rf, Rin)
print(f'Gain = {gain:.0f}x')
print(f'Vout = {Vout:.2f} V')
